title: How many total cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. will The COVID Tracking Project report as of Sunday 26 April 2020?
preds: We would need daily cases well outside the data over the last month for any different outcome.

This is getting really close. Up trend in the latest numbers. Revising with my old methodology for the last few days (need to average 29.592k over the next two days, that has happened 12 times in 24 so far this month), would put me at 50/50. No evidence I can see that the weekends have fewer cases (although weirdly some indication Saturdays are high and Sundays are low). However, you are also seeing upwards revisions in previous numbers, and the last two days numbers seem very high versus earlier in the week in what could be the start of a trend rather than noise. Going for 60/40 which is a 20-25% chance we are in a higher cases regime (maybe due to the run down of social distancing, or spreading in non-distanced areas) and 75-80% numbers are broadly similar to the last month, which would have suggest 50/50

According to the covid tracking project website [1], on Apr 22 there was 859,318 positive cases. This means there are 4 days left until the Apr 26 results.  To reach 950,000 there would need to be a daily average of 22,671 positive cases. That is significantly lower than the current daily numbers. Reaching 1,000,000 would need 35,171 cases per day, with the weekend coming up this is unlikely. [1] https://covidtracking.com/data/us-daily

I consider this as settled: Today's [0] update for Apr 22 confirms the graph [1] projections for two consecutive days (and in retrospection for many, many, many more days). updated for number of test doubling, but taking into account a stable trend of 20-25-30k cases per day; the next two days are critical to understand how higher number of tests will translate into higher number of cases.

Based on the wisdom of the crowd and some modelling. I am making an assumption that the US will not change its counting method, start including other deaths as COVID like what happened in China and Europe, or significantly changing its testing. But the possibility of this makes me less confident my decision.

Some very interesting data was posted today at 4pm.
The # of new tests was more than DOUBLE the previous day, AND the average for the previous week!
The # of new positive cases, however, was less than the average for the previous week.
This made the % of new positive cases (8.7%) about 1/2 of what it has been running. WEIRD. If the # of tests continues at this higher rate, the chances of my estimate for total # of positive cases is more likely to be exceeded than not met, so I'm shifting  to the range I expect the outcome to be in.
My estimate is coming in almost exactly at 950k.

To end up in bucket 3, flow could either: 1. Reduce to an average of c.18,500. This level hasn't been seen since 27 March and would be a drop of a third from current levels, which would be unlikely in the next 4 days, though pending cases have reduced dramatically in last 3 days (two thirds drop 3 days ago, but pending cases haven't been that predictive in the short term); or  2. Increase to an average of c.30,700. This is an 11% increase on the last week average, but it would need to maintain that level for 4 days. This has only happened on 4 days in the last 3 weeks and the average is now dropping.
My logistic model just crossed the Rubicon..

I get a number very close to 950k.  My range is 934k to 960k on Sunday, but the question resolves as of  the next day.  This is my third time answering this question, and  I still do not  know  what "as of Monday.." means after reading the  information on the Covid Tracking Project website.     If anyone does know, please reply.

*NEW MODEL* I'm throwing away my old model [1] as I found it too finicky to small daily percent changes, and didn't keep me ahead of the crowd. So, I'm introducing a new model [1] that does the following: 1. Projects linearly based on declining growth slope since (what looks like) the peak on Fri, Apr 10th
2. Adjusts for day of week variation - there's clear day-of-week variation where counts on Sat/Sun/Mon/Tue are lower than expected if following a perfect linear slope, and counts on Wed/Thu/Fri are higher than expected. See graph on model spreadsheet.
3. Dials up the confidence by reducing standard deviation around the projected mean (projected count minus today's count, divided by 6) On a side note, it should also be much easier to look at for all of you who've been peeking at my models each day! Forecast: 932,200
Previous days: 932,640, 929,992 [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1019459

As of now, there are about 800,000 cases reported, therefore I don’t expect these numbers to go up drastically in the next couple of days.

799,178 as of 21st April - that means:
<850k =  <10k case per day
<900k = <20k case per day
<950k = <30k case per day
<1m = <40k case per day
<1.05m = <50k case per day
<1.1m, <60k case per day To get to under 10k case per day feels like you need something really major (in reality probably stopping testing) as you have to go back to 25th March for a 5 day period that had less than 10k cases per day. ~1%. 850k - 900k also feels implausible (back to 30th March). ~2%. For all of April the daily positives they report have generally been in the mid to high 20k or low 30 k range, so the next two have to be our base case. 4 in 21 rolling 5 day periods since April 1st cases have been below the ~30k number. The numbers also seem to be dropping from a high for the period ending 13th April. If we want to put 90% of the probability between these two, that would imply 73% in 900-950k and 17% in 950-1m. I am tempted to keep those as are - feels like there is an upside skew to the potential number of cases, given this is spreading and given there seems to be a real risk of some of the social distancing measures being ignored, but if the current measures hold strong, we are quite a bit past the last time we had 30k cases per day on average. Put 5% in 1m to 1.05m given the comment on skew and then 1% each in the remaining buckets given they would need a really big step up.

Take the average of the last 5 days, then multiply by 5 days as  the number left and then add on the current number, leaves 936 174 on the 26. While taking the average of the last 10 days, but leaving the rest gives 938 154 cases on the 26. So a slight decline in the recent days compared to longer term, but with between 27 and 30 thousand new cases a day, even an estimate of 930 000 leaves an entire days worth of cases from falling into the 2nd bin. While the trend of the last days speak against any increase that will push it over 950 000, but it is possible. So the by far most likely scenario is between 900 and 950 thousand cases.
Based on current trend and lack of lockdown in many states
Cases are growing ~ 4.4% each day based on a 7-day rolling average. Calculated from 4/22 with 825041 cases and using 4.2 gives 963,000 on April 26 (using a range of 4.0 - 4.4%:  957,000  -- 970,000.)

The total cumulative number of positive cases in the U.S. has increased by a rate of roughly 25K per day since last wednesday. 799K plus 125K (25K per day until sunday, inclusive) yields an estimate of 924K. The rate has also been on a slow downward trend, while testing has remained relatively flat at around 150K tests per day. While some states are beginning to open their economies and parks/beaches again, the effects of these actions on number of positive cases is unlikely to be seen until next week and beyond.
Smaller gain then expected yesterday, possible downward trend in day to day  new case

The Project figures have been consistently higher than my own 1-2-3 count. For that Sunday, the count would be have been 944,000 in my books. Thus, I assume the Project's figures topping that number, pushing it over the 950,000 threshold. The 1-2-3 count is a logistic regression curve on the daily-added figures. Flaws: I have not A) transformed the figures by a natural log and B) the logistic regression curve doesn't bend downwards.

As in the past, this isn't a projection of the reality, but a forecast on the capacity of the project to accumulate information. The project volunteers are very active by the weekend, there were two, three weeks of weekends with high entries that turns low on Mondays and slowly builds up towards the weekend.  For some reason, the daily added new positives in, both, the ECDC (European) and in this project have been steady around 30,000. Since the resolution date is a weekend, just add a couple of thousand to it.

Averaging daily cases for past 7 days. There were 27,193 new cases reported today, 23,321 the day before and so on.

Similarly to what I did with the April 12th and April 19th questions [1][2], I'm using a crude pseudo-model [3] that takes the average logistic (S-/sigmoid) curve of all countries (from ECDC via OurWorldInData.org [4]), starting from each country's first day of 100 cases, using current U.S. data from The COVID Tracking Project [5] to place it on the curve using the average of the last three days' growth rates, and projecting the curve from that point forward to April 26th. I then get the median from the last three days of April 26th projections to establish a my official projection. I do this to smooth out potential growth rate volatility from one day to the next. To find the probabilities for each bin, I then set a max upward bound of the difference of the projected mean and the latest count. I'll update my model and forecast daily. Current forecasts (most recent at right):
4/21: 795,905 (actual: 799,717)
4/22: 818,811 | 827,548

4/25: 880,345 | 897,518

Standard deviation: 32,490 up / 30,223 down My forecast: 1%, 24%, 57%, 17%, 1%, 0%, 0%

The daily reduction in the total case growth rate has been steady at about 6% since social distancing took effect.  900,000 total cases is the centroid of my estimate using the last two weeks of cases data, and the uncertainty is slightly biased to the downside.  I'd like the bands to have a center at 900,000, but they don't.

My (logistic, fit Gompertz) model gives estimate in the 2nd bucket, but it does look that it may underestimate the number due to positives creeping up more than expected. And the estimate is close to the 3rd bucket anyway... So I am dividing odds between the 2nd and 3rd bucket. May reconsider down the road

The rate of infections is showing signs of slowing down as restrictions etc start to take effect. Signs of a growing infection rate in the interior states will potentially give indications of a second peak. This will require an adjustment and further evaluation.

I am not only focusing on the current trajectory but considering a social shift in those who had symptoms but hesitated to travel publically, who may now have a change in perception about individual risk, and a willingness to travel to get tested. This factor is also coupled with political pressure to show an efficient testing regime in the U.S., where testing at the state level will continue to be encouraged.

I looked @ the # of cases last Sunday - they were at about 700,000. I have seen cases doubling day by day & week by week. Using the multiplier of doubling, I am predicting about, 1,400,000 cases by next Sunday

Ballpark first forecast based on simple math Avg # tests per day for the last 8 days = 150,025 . . . 
   (fun fact: during that period on 4 out of 7 days fewer people were tested than on the previous day) Avg # of new tests are positive in the last 7 days = 28,197
  (fun fact:  the days with the lowest % of positive cases were the days when the # of tests increased the most = test more people and the % positive falls) Because the variation in the # of new tests is so great on a day to day basis,  and there's no clear trajectory of increasing or decreasing rates of testing, I'm going to use the avg # of tests per day. Because the % of new cases seems to be linked more closely to the # of tests than to the date, I"m going to use the avg % of new cases. Therefore:  I going to start off assuming that  150,025 x 7 = 1,050,175 new tests will be done by 4/26
and that 18.6% of those tests will be positive , so 1,050,175 x .186 = 195,332 new positive cases 195,332 + 749,203 (current count) = 944,535 positive cases by EoD 4/26 OR using the average of 28,197 new positive cases per day in the last 7 days = 197,379
197,379 + 749,203 = 946,582 positive cases by EoD 4/26 What might impact the rate of positive cases:
Decrease due to social distancing
Increase due to delay between exposure & symptoms EDIT:  @marktscannell EDIT 2:  
https://hal-pasteur.archives-ouvertes.fr/pasteur-02548181
"France . . .  went into lockdown on the 17th March 2020. . . .  The lockdown reduced the reproductive number from 3.3 to 0.5 (84% reduction).. . . " I'm assuming that the lockdown in the US will have/is having a similar effect.

The rate of doubling has been decreasing in the past weeks 
4/19/20 it was approximately 13 days
4/13/20 it was approximately 10 days
4/06/20 it was approximately 6 days at this rate of decrease with diminishing returns I expect it will be doubling at approximately 15 days on 4/26/2020 which would mean ~1,060,000 cases
If I look at it more optimistically, we don't have diminishing returns lowering the rate of doubling then I would say maybe 16 days, which would mean ~1,004,000 cases
However, some states have gotten stricter on their social distancing requirements, so we could see results from that in decreasing the rate of spread further, which is why I give any chance of being less than 950,000.
I also see a large chance that the numbers end up higher from expanded testing if it happens.

March 26 - April 3 average = 23581
April 3 -  April 11 average = 30923
April 11 - April 19 average =  28295 To reach between 900,000 and 950,000 the rate would need to average between 21,542 and 28,685 per day
To reach between 950,000 and 1,000,000 the rate would need to average between 28,685 and 35,828 per day  I think the average will increase slightly over the next week because the USA appears to still be in the growth stage of their graph. I'm expecting an average of around 30000 per day. Case numbers on Sunday and Monday have consistently been fewer. Therefore, today's result will probably be lower than the average.

The 7 day trend however is positive by 272 cases per day which would result in 961000 cases on the 26th of April 28 % above 950000
